clinical_study.brief_title: Defining the Best Approach to Block the Pain After Knee Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Defining the Best Approach to Block the Pain After Knee Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The study aims to compare standard techniques used to control pain after knee surgery. The investigators hypothesize that the fascia iliaca block is faster, safer and as good as or better than the femoral block, with or without a stimulating catheter.

detailed_description.textblock:
60 patients being treated for ACL repair or knee arthroplasties under regional anesthesia will be randomized to three groups: Fascia Iliaca Block (FIB), Femoral Block (FB) with stimulating catheter or FB without stimulating catheter. A catheter will be placed according to each technique, before the surgery. A bolus of local anesthetic will be given pre-surgery and at the end of the operation, in all groups. A continuous infusion will be started for 48 hours. All patients receive a standard analgesia cocktail and rescue medication.
Pain and level of activity, as well as side effects, will be evaluated.

primary_outcome.measure: pain relief; measured by VAS at rest and on activity
primary_outcome.time_frame: before surgery, before discharge from PACU and on evenings of days 1, 2, 7, 60, 90

primary_outcome.measure: pain relief; evaluated from standard datasheet

secondary_outcome.time_frame: measured before surgery, and at days 7, 60, 90

secondary_outcome.measure: thigh circumference 20 cm above the knee
secondary_outcome.time_frame: measured before surgery and at days 7, 60, 90

secondary_outcome.measure: neurological exam of femorocutaneous, femoral and obturator nerves
secondary_outcome.time_frame: evaluated once spinal anesthesia has worn off, post-surgery, before anesthesia

secondary_outcome.measure: level of activity; measured using questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at 7-10 days and at 2 and 3 months
in recovery room and at home

secondary_outcome.measure: need for second bolus or crossing over between groups

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients coming for ACL or knee prosthesis surgery
- Between 18-80 years old
- Consenting for spinal anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Major neurologic diseases
- Obesity with body mass index (BMI) > 30
- Infection at the punction sites (back and/or groin)
- Diabetes mellitus for longer than 5 years
- Coagulopathy
